comments.body: Bumped the minor version
Added two new methods, `validateAt` and `validateSyncAt`
Good point. Returning `any` is what lodash does with `_.get`, which is why I started using idx instead.

`test` can now take a function as message and it gets passes some data to use to compose an error message. The documentation around this is not all that defined and tracing through the code, I found properties that I listed in `TestMessageParams` but there could be more so I set the type as a union of `object` and the partial.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +78,82 @@        message:
            | string
            | ((params: object & Partial<TestMessageParams>) => string),
        test: (
            this: TestContext,

comments.body: Another addition, this basically lists out the properties that I found in the code.
Since test has both an config object style callsign and an arguments style callback, I also added the new changes to `message` here too.

Shouldn't the line above also change to make the `value` argument no longer optional? Doing so would accurately distinguish between the "has a single argument" and "has no argument" overloads, which have different return types.
Good point - yes, I believe you are correct
I'm guessing some of these changes are like prettier changes?
Yes sorry, I have prettier with format on save enabled. You want me to revert these?
Oh no. I like prettier being run on the code!
I think we should call this type `WhenOptionsFunction<T>` because the docs call the second argument `builder` when it's an object.
`builder` is the name of the argument when it is an object or function. I was trying to stick with the existing naming scheme, but add more specificity.
Yeah, okay. I'll concede. ðŸ˜„

Since `is` can actually be anything, are we losing of the type information if we just change this type to `((...values: any[]) => boolean) | any` rather than a union of all these types?

Furthermore, can we name this type something like `BuilderIsProperty` or `WhenIsProperty` or simply `IsProperty` so that it doesn't sound like a ruby method name?

Yes. Unioning anything with `any` resolves to just `any`. I believe this is even a linter warning. The way I have it allows for all the types I tested with, but still gives some intellisense/direction about what the `when` method expects.

I think `IsProperty` is too generic. What if there were another `is` property that took different types. Likewise with `BuilderIsProperty`. There could be other methods that take a builder of a different sort. Again, I was trying to stick with and expand the existing naming convention.
I'm still not a fan of the name but I don't see that as a reason to block this PR from being merged.
We should just call this `WhenOptionsBuilder` to match the documentation for yup.
Referring back to the 1st comment. `builder` can be an object or function, so suffixing them makes sense to me to distinguish them.
I think having these types are clutch!

Thanks :-)

When this PR is merged I will do a PR on the yup docs to show how to use this.
We might need to flip the order of these function declarations for the types to flow correctly?
I think you actually need another overload for `boolean`, but I'm not sure what to return. Just `NumberSchema<T>`?
Shouldn't the boolean overload go last since it will otherwise match literal `true` and `false`?
Yeah, I'm thinking this too.
Agreed, added the various overloads and a test for them.

I agree with ðŸ‘‡ statement pretty wholeheartedly

> Personally I would favor more complexity in the type definition with a simple API over a simple type definition and a more complex API for developers to use.

I do wonder though, how many of our clients are using wrapper code like that because if that's somewhat of an "advanced" usecase, then I'm okay having the types be conditional so that we can get some of the benefits of simpler types on the type author side as well.
@kalley just add your name and GH profile url here :)
Any reason this needs to be an interface? I think it would be clearer as `type InnerInferTypeArray<T> = Array<InnerInferType<T>>;`

good question â€“ it's because you can't use a type alias there; if you do, you get errors about type aliases not being able to recursively reference themselves. this limitation doesn't apply to interfaces.

I was wondering about the reason for `interface InnerInferTypeArray<T>` in the fist place as it doesn't add any members from `Array<InnerInferType<T>>` so just using the laster should be the same. But I noticed compile errors with TypeScript@3.6 while TypeScript@3.7 has no compile errors.

LGTM

I would add a comment here explaining that `| undefined | null` is added intentionally because the test will still run for undefined/null input whether or not they're set to be allowed. Otherwise inevitably someone else will submit a PR to remove that.
